description: This tour will look at the development of Bedford Park in Chiswick, the first garden suburb. We will consider the social and architectural influences on the design of this unique community.

factsheet.heading: About the tour and guide
paragraphs: Bedford Park is a suburban development in Chiswick designed by Jonathan Carr in 1875 and featuring buildings by Norman Shaw and other leading Victorian architects. Bedford Park has been described as the world's first garden suburb, creating a model of apparent informality emulated around the world. The development is protected by a conservation area in the London Borough of Ealing, and a smaller one in the London Borough of Hounslow. Over 350 of its buildings are Grade II-listed; the church and the inn are Grade II*-listed.

Topics covered in the tour:
- Developments in London leading to expansion of suburbs
- History of the project
- Social history underlying the development of Bedford Park (“BP”)
- The Queen Anne Revival Style
     - Development
     - Use on specific buildings
- The decline and resurrection of BP
- The definition of a “garden suburb” vs. a “garden city”
Guide: Louise Vannier loves exploring cities. Her interests include European medieval art and architecture, textiles, the Arts and Crafts movement and the Modernist movement.

factsheet.heading: Golden Key Academy
paragraphs: This tour is led by a participant of Open City’s Golden Key Academy – a course training up insightful and engaging guides dedicated to explaining London and bringing its many stories to life. It is part of a wider collection of tour events created by Golden Key Academy guides for the Open House Festival celebrating their conclusion of the six month course.
Further info on the Golden Key Academy https://open-city.org.uk/golden-key-academy

factsheet.heading: Tour meeting point:
paragraphs:
Outside Turnham Green Tube Station 
Turnham Green Terrace
W4 1LR

name: Walking tour of Bedford Park
